Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my delivery uniform still clinging to me from the morning’s rush. The last package on my route was for a house on the edge of town, and the instructions were clear: leave it only if someone was home. I rang the bell twice, but no one answered. My phone buzzed—a reminder that Friday prayers would begin in less than an hour. As the imam, I was expected to deliver the Khutbah, but today, a guest speaker was prepared and waiting in case I couldn’t make it. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “No exceptions—secure the package, confirm delivery.” But the congregation expected me to be there, to guide them, to fulfill my duty as their imam. I stood on the porch, package in hand, heart pounding, torn between the trust placed in me by my employer and the spiritual responsibility I owed my community. The weight of both uniforms pressed on my shoulders as I stared at the silent door, wrestling with which expectation I would have to let down.
